Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act
responses:
Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act, 1957:
 this is the central legislation that regulates the mining sector in India. It governs the allocation of mineral concessions, mineral rights, and the regulation of mining operations. The act has been amended several times to keep pace with changing requirements and environmental concerns.

Mineral Conservation and Development Rules, 1988:
These rules, framed under the Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act, provide guidelines for the conservation and sustainable development of minerals. They cover various aspects of mining, including reconnaissance, prospecting, and mining operations.

Coal Mines (Special Provisions) Act, 2015:
This act deals specifically with the allocation of coal blocks for mining and the auction of coal mines. It was enacted to address issues related to coal block allocations and transparency in the coal mining sector..

National Mineral Policy, 2019: 
 Although not an act, the National Mineral Policy provides a framework for the development and regulation of the mineral sector in India. It emphasizes sustainable mining practices, community development, and the welfare of mining-affected people.

The Mineral (Auction) Rules, 2015:
 These rules were formulated to conduct the auction of mineral blocks, ensuring transparency and competitiveness in the allocation process. It applies to the auction of various minerals, including iron ore and bauxite.
